posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69426330

I have issues getting to my TDEE partially due to my weird work schedule, but if I could munch some bread and fruit get’em calories and keep going that’d be great

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69436076
If you're talking about ladies HIIT class stuff
you're not using like a normal hypertrophy focused set rep scheme. You're doing high rep stuff not near failure because you're preforming them faster than normal but carefully you don't want momentum at the end of the range of motion.
Like say you take pair of 5-10 lb dbs do 12 squats, 12 pushups using the DBs as grips, get up to your knees row 12 reps, stand up do 12 lateral raises, 12 ohps, some pullups you just cycle through those as quickly as you can as long as you can until you really feel like your heart is redlining. Then walk until your heartrate is back down to around 50% of your max safe heart rate then do it like 9-14 more times.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Please research videos on water fasting.

It sounds counter intuitive... how can eating nothing be easier than restricting your calories?

If you eat nothing you stop producing hormones that give the feeling of hunger. I have been trying to lose weight for a decade via the conventional method (500 cal deficit and daily workout).

The daily battle of not losing my 500 deficit required a lot of willpower and determination.

With water fasting I have truly found my own personal solution. I have been eating only on Saturdays for almost two months now (last two weeks kinda iffy bc holidays). I am down 30lbs.

My hunger has reduced. I feel more clean. I have more energy. My mentality clarity has improved. And I actually crave going to workout when fasting.

Don't take my work for it. All I'm saying is look it up and don't dismiss it entirely. There is a cool YouTube video of "what happens if I don't eat for 7 days".

Also tip , take electrolytes seriously. It's a night and day effect on your overall body and mood.

Here are a few steps you can take to become more athletic:

Set specific, achievable goals: Decide what you want to achieve, such as running a certain distance or lifting a certain amount of weight. Having specific goals will help you stay motivated and on track.

Develop a training plan: Consider hiring a personal trainer or consulting with a coach to help you develop a training plan that is tailored to your goals and fitness level. A training plan should include a combination of cardiovascular exercise, strength training, and flexibility work.

Find activities you enjoy: Choose activities that you enjoy, as this will make it more likely that you will stick with them. This could be a team sport, an individual sport, or a recreational activity such as hiking or cycling.

Stay consistent: To see progress, it's important to be consistent with your training. Aim to exercise at least three times a week, and gradually increase the intensity and duration of your workouts as you become more fit.

Stay hydrated and properly nourished: Proper hydration and nutrition are important for optimal athletic performance. Make sure you're getting enough fluids and eating a balanced diet that includes a variety of nutrients.

Get plenty of rest and recovery: Make sure to allow your body time to rest and recover between workouts. This will help reduce the risk of injury and allow your muscles to repair and grow.

With hard work and dedication, you can become more athletic and improve your physical fitness.

Build it up slowly over time
Practice “opening” yourself in conversations - I don’t know how to explain it but it’s when you genuinely seek to speak to a person’s heart, rather than just interacting with them as a talking object.
If you can’t do this, try it on the checkout cashier. Don’t just make random small talk, but instead look at the person and try and feel what they’re feeling, and from that you can match their energy.
The next thing to do is to go to places where there are people who are like you (or like who you want to be) and LARP. I’m not kidding, what you need is a social persona. Fake it till you make it. If you struggle to naturally fake it, think about someone you know who is really popular and cool, and imagine yourself as acting the same way. If you can believe that you are popular and cool, then very soon you will become popular and cool.
Another anon said psycho-cybernetics is a good book, you can get pdf on Google.
Also, PUA meme aside, the mystery method explains places you should go to and spatial awareness in social situations

>>69424313
This is all good advice and 100% what I did back in 2009 to overcome social anxiety and become a social butterfly in college. Psycho-Cybernetics, LARPing as a social persona, etc. Amusingly the PUA meme was what gave me the idea that I could learn social skills and improve, so it worked out for the best.

Regarding deriving reward from social interactions, taking natural introversion or extroversion out of the equation for a moment, I think one factor is that people tend to not enjoy what they suck at. Think about learning a new skill, like learning to play the guitar, or first starting at the gym, or whatever... It feels like a chore at first until you gain enough skill to start deriving reward from it. Socializing is the same. I had social anxiety and low level social skills that I had to learn from scratch, so I set little mini goals for myself each day that would gradually get more difficult, like starting a conversation with someone from class, or holding eye contact, stuff like that. Went from always turning red, stuttering, and feeling butterflies in my stomach to being really comfortable socially and a lot of friends I made in college recalled meeting me through me randomly talking to them.

Succeedsocially.com is also a really good site I used way back then that covers a lot of the absolute basics of social skills and starting conversations if you're an absolute sperg starting from scratch.

>Advice for new runners
- Try to keep your cadence high (at or around 180 steps per minute)
- Try to keep your heartrate in Zone1/2 (around an average of 55-65% of your max. heart rate)

- Don't worry about form, the human body knows how to run, just do what comes naturally
- Once you can comfortably run 6 mi. (10km), start thinking about a goal in terms of race distance and time, and look for a training routine for that race

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I spent several hours looking this stuff up online a few weeks ago. A few takeaways I learned were that (according to the research):

1. Runners should lift weights twice a week, specifically on their hard days. So if Tuesday is track work and Friday is tempo, you lift those days.

2. Weight lifting should be done at least 3 hours after finishing the run. So run in the morning and lift in late afternoon or early evening would be the norm.

3. Warn up and cool down for 5-10 minutes of easy cardio, preferably non-impact.

4. Use 3 sets of 5-10 reps per exercise with about 60 seconds rest. Goal is to lift heavy.

5. Runners who consistently lift twice a week reduce injuries by one third. So, for example 3 injuries over a certain time period without lifting weights would have only been 2 injuries with weight lifting.

6. Lifting can improve running economy by up to 8%, but most will likely be in the middle (3-5%).

7. Try to prioritize compound exercises.

8. Upper body lifts prioritize chest, back, and shoulders for better running posture.

9. Routine should start with 1 squat, 1 hip hinge, 1 lunge, 1 push for chest, 1 pull for back, and 1 shoulder exercise. Over time, it's okay to expand the routine and do more than that, but it should at least be comprised of that.

10. During the taper, you taper weight training as well. So the routine stays the same, but instead of lifting twice a week, you only lift once a week.

>>69421141
From my experience there are some sport-specific things you need to do, depending on your weaknesses.
>tight hips
Psoas march
>shin splints
Tibialis raise or heel walk
>calves
Calf raise, one normal, plus one bent knee to work soleus.
>extra
Lunges are overpowered for running. Also do farmers walk with knee raise, plus soleus variation like calves.

Also
>lift heavy
I agree, but I would recommend lifting like a bitch at first, go through motions and leave a lot in the tank until your body gets used to the full routine.

>>69423900
>Walking with little to no support as with zero drop shoes on hard surfaces allows our foot to collapse which can lead to a tremendous amount of stress not only to the foot but to the rest of the body. Our feet naturally pronate during the gait cycle, however when we walk with no to no support we pronate for a longer period of time which then alters the biomechanics and distribution of pressure and weight across the foot. This imbalance may increase the progression of underlying foot deformities such as bunions and hammertoes and lead to painful conditions associated with excessive pronation such as arch/ heel pain, shin splints/ posterior tibial tendonitis, and Achilles tendonitis. This imbalance can then translate upward affecting other parts of the body such as our knees and back.

so basically the shoes bait you to injure yourself?

>How the fuck does a pasty-ass redhead like me get a tan?
Beta karotene supplements and use sunscreen when you are in the sun for long periods. Moisturize your skin after you've tanned and drinks lots of water on summer months.

>The skin on my body that's usually exposed to the sun (anything not covered up by a t-shirt and shorts) has an almost permanent tan; even in the winter months it doesn't completely go away, but anything under my clothes burns with even a little bit of exposure to the sun on a hot day.
That's because the skin that isn't covered has gotten conditioned from gradual sun exposure to produce more melanin. The covered skin hasn't gotten that stimulus. You can condition it as well, but it is a long process and burning will only damage the skin and not tan it so avoid that. Start with short times and gradually increase them. Use sunscreen if you are gonna be out for long periods. Beta karotene also protects somewhat from burning and helps tanning a bit.

It's possible that the increased physical activity of going back to the gym is causing you to be more tired and requiring more sleep. When you're more active, your body uses more energy, which can lead to increased fatigue. Additionally, if you're not used to being active, it can take your body some time to adjust to the increased activity level. It's also possible that your body is still in a state of recovery from the month-long break, and your increased sleep needs are a result of that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
i read the other day that if your workout is over an hour long, that's about the mark where cortisol increases and you might be doing more harm than good. obviously massive variables there, but in general i'd say try limiting how much time you spend on any given workout, and make sure you get some food in you once you're done.
try one of those meal replacement shakes, for something balanced that'll be quickly absorbed. sometimes people forget there's more to diet than protein and zinc.

on that point, exercise isn't just demanding of energy, it's demanding of several nutrients, hence the whole 'zma' thing in the first place. you might be leaving yourself slightly deficient/depleted if you're placing all this demand on your body but not replacing what you're using up.
electrolyes are an obvious one, but even just being dehydrated can be super fatigue inducing - the change when I started actually remembering to bring my water bottle to the gym vs just chugging a glass on the way out was night and day.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Chinups have a more complete range of motion for the lats and place your biceps in the most advantageous position which further facilitates lat development whereas pullups cause the biceps to fail and the set to end earlier. I hope that makes sense. I'm EFL.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69433983
Pull-ups and chin-ups are both exercises that work your upper body muscles, including your biceps, shoulders, and back. The main difference between the two exercises is the grip that you use.

In a pull-up, you grip the bar with your palms facing away from your body (also known as an overhand grip). This grip targets your back muscles more, specifically the latissimus dorsi (also known as the "lats").

In a chin-up, you grip the bar with your palms facing towards your body (also known as an underhand grip). This grip targets your biceps more and also works your back muscles.

Both pull-ups and chin-ups are excellent exercises for building upper body strength, so it's a good idea to include both in your workout routine.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I have one in my lower back, the worst thing to do is try to lift through it. If you get early symptoms, go to the doctor and do physical therapy for a month or so, DO NOT LIFT HEAVY.

Got one and thought I was being a pussy about it and continued to lift heavy until the pain became unbearable and the injury became permanent.

You cannot get rid of a herniated disc, but can limit the pain. I went from being in constant agony to minimum pain after a year of having it.

My hernia is in my lower back so it might be different depending on where its located but this did it for me.
>Stop lifting heavy compounds all the time, ohp/bench
>STOP squatting or deadlifting period
>Replace everything with calisthenic counterpart, once the pain decrease enough, start doing them weighted to build strength.
>Get a stiff mattress and sleep in a fetal position.
>If you sit at a desk a lot, switch to a standing desk.
>Do core exercises, strength it as much as possible
>Take anti inflammatory meds when it flares up
>Avoid any weird twisting movements
>Do spine decompression
>Give it time, after a year or so the hernia shrinks a bit.

I went from constant back breaking pain, to almost nothing. Weighted pushups and pullups are extremely effective as well, ignore the SS rippletards. I am way stronger than i was before on bench, ohp and rows while being pain free.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69432608
There are several treatment options for a herniated disc, and the best course of action will depend on the severity of your symptoms and the underlying cause of the herniation. Some treatment options include:

Rest and physiotherapy: In some cases, rest and physiotherapy may be enough to allow the herniated disc to heal on its own. Your physiotherapist can teach you exercises to help reduce pain and improve mobility.

Medications: Your doctor may prescribe pain medication to help manage your symptoms. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) such as ibuprofen and naproxen can help reduce swelling and pain.

Epidural injections: An epidural injection delivers corticosteroids directly to the area around the spinal cord, which can help reduce inflammation and pain.

Surgery: In severe cases, surgery may be necessary to repair or remove the herniated disc. There are several different types of surgery that can be used to treat a herniated disc, including microdiscectomy, laminectomy, and spinal fusion.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69425539
This might be common sense, but if you don't know any movements, and I'm talking about the ballistic style movements, then just pick one or two and work them for a couple weeks or a month, then switch to a different couple of movements for another interval. When I started KB stuff, I was trying to learn everything at once. For example, when I took dedicated time to work on my cleans, then took some time off to work snatches, when I came back to cleans it felt alot better. Just my two cents.
Also on a side note, I'm almost convinced KB combined with calisthenics is some of the most complete training. When I did solely free weights, it always felt like my progress only transfered to lifts instead of my everyday life. Not going on some functional strength speech, but the difference is crazy. Makes me think all the time I spent moving furniture was progressing my deadlift more than the work I put in actually deadlifting. Not to mention I felt my slowest when I was my strongest. I feel like I've got my perfect balance going for speed, strength and power now. Trying to figure out how to work in some yoga to get my mobility back

>>69427513
I got 2 KB workouts and 1 calisthetic workout in rotation. I do the KB stuff in circuits with 5 sets and 1min rest between. Calisthenics is circuits as well but the timing is more complicated than I want to explain, but I do 20 sets.
KB Balistic Workout
>90lb clean x5 each arm
>35lb snatch x10 each arm
>53lb swing x10 each arm
>2x53lb long cycle x8
>90lb two hand swing x10
KB Strength
>90lb goblet squat x10
>2x53lb ohp x8
>2x53lb deadlift x10
>53lb bent rows x10 each arm
>35lb overhead lunges x8 each leg
>90lb two hand swing x10
Calisthenics
>15x push-ups
>5x pullups

I started with a 12kg but I was auschwitz mode for ~2 years at 16BMI then turned skinnyfat; so I had barely any muscle.
Well I actually started with a 8L jug and some duct tape, but I quickly outgrew it; and outgrew the 12kg in 4~5 months.

If you're just regular DYEL then a 16kg is fine to start with, if you can't OHP it yet then you can most definitely floor press it.
Personally I found that 12kg is a bit too light for learning snatches and stuff, so unless you are REALLY weak and not just regular DYEL just go with a 16kg.

Just know that if you can OHP it then you can snatch it. Of course don't try snatching before you have good shoulder mobility and such, because getting the technique right at first is going to be moderately difficult.

Question about dfw
When you finish the program length
Do you just do a set for as many as possible on the last days?
Do you add weight, reduce rest, or add total time?
I haven't found good info on that or on kettlebell progression in general
I've actually been doing dfw, but at the end of each cycle (using the two 40lb weights) I do a set of as many as possible then reduce rest between sets by 10 seconds
Once I've done a cycle with 60 seconds of rest between sets I'm going to add 5 minutes each cycle until I'm at 45 minutes
Then I'll use the 50 lb weights and go back to 90 second rest between sets for 30 minutes
Hope that's not confusing

>>69433314
I truly believe that if you're not a semi pro powerlifter, you probably won't ever need anything more than a half rack. Most lifters aren't even 100% amateur bodybuilders, they're generally very jack of all trades. I truly believe that a half rack, weight plates, barbell, adjustable dumbbells, adjustable bench, dip bar, rings, dipping belt, 2 pulleys (1- on the ceiling and another 1 on the floor), ropes (to use them as dumbbells for overhead tricep extension for example) and maybe bands are all that you will ever need for life. This list of equipment will get you years and years of variety and will allow you to train for different goals and activities. Lots of stuff you can DIY quite safely as well. Like the Hungarian core blaster (or the DIY T shaped kettlebell) for swings.
No need to be buying all the new toys like you're fucking kid. Focus on the important stuff, do the most with what you have and only then try to find a way to do other stuff with what you already have.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Emi edition.

>Who is /fat/ for?
For titular tubsters who are working towards a better physique through meaningful hard-work, strategy, and dedication. This is not QTDDTOT, stick to questions on fat loss. Post height and weight when asking for advice.
Join our Fatty Contest: https://www.fattycontest.com/

>What do I do first?
1. Read https://physiqonomics.com/fat-loss/
2. Calculate your Body Fat Percentage: https://fitness.bizcalcs.com/Calculator.asp?Calc=Body-Fat-Navy
3. Calculate your TDEE: https://www.sailrabbit.com/bmr/
Remember to use bodyfat% and use Katch-McArdle Formula with sedentary settings or your TDEE will be too high.
4. Plan your weight loss: https://www.losertown.org/eats/cal.php
5. Track your nutrition with MyFitnessPal (better for packaged food), Cronometer (better for generic food/macros) or LoseIt (great for both).

>Now what?
Count calories, all of them.
Eat about 500-1000 less calories than your TDEE.
Buy scales, be accurate.
Learn to cook. Try to stick to lean protein and green vegetables.
Eat a lot of protein. 0.72g per lb of goal lean body mass.
Doing cardio, even just walking, will improve your health. There is no such thing as a healthy fat heart, but you can offset the risks.
Lifting weights will keep and gain muscle mass and burn fat much quicker. No lifting results in the body burning away muscle AND fat.
Drink more water.
Read the /fit/ sticky: https://liamrosen.com/fitness.html

>DON'T
Eat refined sugars, they're terrible for you regardless of calories.
Eat processed foods.
Drink your calories (alcohol, soda, starbucks).
Freak out over a weight loss stall. Plateaus can last up to three weeks.
"Reward" yourself. Cheat days cheat only yourself.

>Other resources:
Loose skin, gyno & stretch marks: https://weight-loss-side-effects.netlify.app/
Reddit wiki: https://www.reddit.com/r/loseit/wiki/faq

>If my goal was strictly to lose weight, do days off from lifting matter?
days off are essential in getting fit, that's when you grow
but in terms of weightloss it's not that important
THE biggest factor will be diet, not exercise, so don't worry too much about that

>Like lifting burns more calories then say running. So if I lift 6 times a week would that be overkill? Or do I have to rest the muscles?
do whatever you can stick to
if you're new I recommend the usual noob programs like SS or SL, or GSLP if you want more variety
reddit also has a 6 day PPL routine that is for beginners

focus on learning the lifts and then pick a program that motivates you personally
and once you pick one, stick with it for at least a few months
give it time to work
you get paralysis by analysis on /fit/

>>69420760
So for losing weight diet is the #1 most important thing. Having muscles does increase your BMR so you can consume more calories while losing weight, but ultimately thats still up to your diet.

So the question is really are rest days necessary to build muscle. In which case the answer is yes, if youre a noob lifter and youre even able to lift 6 days a week without soreness forcing you to rest you are probably not training hard enough for real gains. More experienced lifters can do that but start with 3 days a week and see how you feel. Even 2 lifting days can be fine.

posts.com:
>>69423804
>I told myself I would quit booze for my new years resolution and I managed to get a head start, been sober for 3 weeks already.
Proud of you my lad.
I've had an "alcohol problem" in my past and used it to deal with pain. I've also had periods of 1yr+ sobriety.
Nov > Dec has been a disaster. Xmas & New Year I've both had 3 days worth of heavy binge drinking booze ready to go and with the intent of drinking over 2 days. Worked at xmas, is underway today with <14 hours to go.

It's hard to quit booze forever for some, but good shit. Remember that if you get a craving just go for it.
Not booze, go for simple carbs, chocolate, treat yourself and take the sugar because it's the same as drinking a beer or booze, less/same calories, less cost and less addicting because you can wean yourself off of it.
Sounds crazy to recommend something like chocolate; a pain point for some.
-but it works and it's easier to wean yourself off of.

I still drink infrequently, usually once every month or 2 but 3 weeks sober for someone who drinks often is good.
Some tips for people looking to cut the raw sugar water out their diet:

>You feel a craving and you're outside shopping? In the supermarket?
Break the pattern, go down another aisle. Buy some chocolate to meet the sugar craving if you think you need it and wean yourself off. Drink another non-addictive sugar water.
>You feel a craving and drink alone or at home?
Try and sleep, sleep through the time you can go and buy booze if you can and see if it passes. Hopefully by the time you wake up it's too late to drink, too late to buy something and you can get through another day.

It's one step at a time and day 5 of sobriety sleeping going into day 6 through sleep helps you get there with the baby steps. Maybe you eat a choco bar for day 7 > 21 and cut down one block a day where you cut out the sugars, you extend the time not taking chocolate are booze and you're off it.
Fucking proud of you, keep it up in January friend.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69421101
>Would eating below BMR actually cause issues? I know it’s sometimes recommended if you’re overly fat and I do have health concerns about losing my entire stomach fat before I’m 30. (I’m turning 25). Would slow and steady win the race or can I maintain a low caloric diet.
It'll trigger the person concerned about the "ketoschizo" because BMR is mentioned but.
There's different theories and camps to weight loss. There's people who believe in huge cuts below BMR, there's people who believe in eating at or slightly below BMR and there's fasters (a more complex issue). That's excluding the idea of exercise. I may need to go into 2 post territory because of char limit but sure.
As a general rule of thumb:
You don't want to eat too much below your BMR long term because it can lower your metabolism and most people can't handle the hunger that comes with it.

The eat sensible/slightly below & stay active crowd have a reasonable plan.
Eat at or slightly below your BMR, stay active to build & mantain muscle, build fat etc and over time you should lose weight, like the turtle, slow and steady wins the race.

>I know it’s sometimes recommended if you’re overly fat
On the harder side (for some people) you have the fasting crowd who require a bunch of willpower but the idea is still generally the same.
Keep up activity (again to maintain metabolism & muscle mass), reduce your eating windows to burn fat over time but again eat AT your BMR and not below (to maintain your metabolism, this is an important thing and you'll see many in these threads do it wrong) on those windows and lose weight.
Fasters can easily fit their macros into a big good meal/window but it's not for everyone for many reasons. Not everyone has the time/flexibility or freedom to fast, to figure out electrolytes, sleep through hunger windows & deal with things like refeeds & eating windows.

cont...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69421101
>>69424874
but in general slow and steady is a good approach and better than crash dieting.
Basically control your portions, eat a bit less, stay active and go at it slow and steady. You can lose more weight just by thinking about when you eat and how you eat and challenging your relationships with food & drink.
Drink a glass of water before & during your feeding windows, chew your food thouroughly (until it's mush into meme territory) and eat less junk.

You mentioned concerns over losing stomach fat before 30 and that's attainable through fasting and even through SENSIBLE CICO targetting a BMR. I believe you can get there if you put in the work but beware that cutting calories by huge amounts & fasting require some research and work if you don't want to destroy your metabolism and remain a functional human being.
If you're a wagie, the biggest thing is remaining functional. Crash diets don't help that because you don't have the time and you need to focus rather than being harassed by ghrelin constantly on a giant cut. If you're a wagie you also have significantly less time for things like fasting too.

Keep it simple & stupid.
Cut slightly below your MBR or target a calorie intake matching an MBR of the weight you want to be and remain active. Good food macros, cut out the junk and eat sensibly and you can do it. If you cut sligtly below (not by retarded amounts) and stay moderately active your metabolism will keep up and you'll make it.
Try a "low caloric" diet like the picture if you wish but it is a crash, you will eventually be hungry, your metabolism will drop and you will be more miserable than taking a sensible approach and learning how to eat.

Whatever you do: good luck anon and don't be afraid to ask more.

>digital scales are usually set to show a cached weight. You can reset it by weighing yourself while holding something heavy and stepping on.
lel, I've legitimately never seen cached weights on digital scales and I've been using them since 2008 when I ditched my mechanical body scales.

My cheap ass smart scales do pretty good at showing a different result every time and even showing which side I'm putting the most weight on (usually 60% on my right side due to a busted knee).
Even low tech digital scales from a reputable (aka shit tier gonna break garbage) brand like Salter will show different results each time.
Also as an aside for people who have special needs, when you place digital scales on the flat surface (yes, you need to put them on a flat surface) step on them for a moment while on and then back off so they zero out. On average digital scales that aren't zeroed or are garbage are usually off by about 1.5 > 2.5 kg if you don't zero them.

>>69424610
Sorry I guess I have a mild tism, for some reason when I read lentils I just think of beans, they're part of the same family but still. For macro purposes cup to cup they're virtually identical, these are cooked values. Lentils typically have a little more protein, beans will have a wider array of micronutrients and also be lower on the GI scale (both are on the fairly low end).

Lentil
230cal
18g protein
40g carb
15g fiber
1g sugar

Beans (pinto)
245cal
15g protein
45g carbs
15g fiber
1g sugar


There's nothing wrong with rice, I initially had problems with using it accordingly in dieting, but have since then rectified and it's a good option but lacking overall in the wider macros/micro department comparatively to lentils/beans. And yes I'm speaking of dry beans, but canned are fine too, you just need to be informed on what's added in the can. I don't have anything for lentils unfortunately specifically as I don't really eat them and there are specific varietals (typically the ones you'll find in Walmart are fine). All you need to do is rinse before hand, and cook in a sauce pan. 3:1 liquid to lentils ratio, could so something like the following as a base.

1tbsp oil (cooking spray is also great to minimize cal)
1 medium white onion
1 celery stalk
1 medium carrot
1tsp cumin
1tsp coriander
1tsp paprika (can add cayenne as well).
3 cups chicken stock
1 cup lentils

Mince all of your vegetables and saute them in the oil to cook down, put in seasonings while you're doing that, once your lentils have been rinsed thoroughly add them and the chicken stock stock to the pot and cook to a boil, then cover and reduce to a simmer for 17-20 minutes. Shorter time for a more toothesome feel, more time for softer.

You can also marinate them but I don't know how healthy that realistically is, as it involves infusing cooking oil and the lentil

(I'm phone fagging right now so I'm making a second post covering beans as I can't really tell how close I am to word limit)

>>69425008
In regards to beans you don't need a pressure cooker per say, but then you also don't need to soak them overnight if you have one. It's a time versus convenience thing. In regards to the "juice" I'm just talking about the residual soaked bean liquid, you don't need it exactly but has a lot of starch so it can be used to thicken with stock, also vegans use it to help meet macros. I forgot to mention in the lentil "chapter" you can play a little with the water ratio for a thicker consistency, also look around for fried lentils as well for a totally non soup/porridge consistency.

Back to beans. I'll give a recipe for roasted Garbanzos that I like and something for brown beans since you mentioned them. The great thing about it is, is that the recipe I gave for lentils also works really well for a wide variety of beans since they're so similar. (You can also play with seasonings to change flavor profiles, I encourage it as it's part of growing as a cook)

Garbanzo Nuts
3 cans drained and patted dry Garbanzo beans
1tbsp evoo (need enough to get a light coating on everything)
1tsp cumin
1tsp cayenne
1tsp garlic powder
1tsp thyme

Mix all ingredients in bowl thoroughly so all beans are coated, preheat oven to 375 and spread out evenly on a lined pan and cook for 20-25 mins or until they're golden brown. Store in container in fridge for up to 4-5 days. Best served day of as they'll be the ccrisper. Can eat them as a snack, throw in salads, etc. Macros are solid too.

Gotta get ready for work but here's a solid recipe I like for baked beans thats /fit/. I'll be around later today if you have questions.

The exercise you're doing is probably too intense and it's depleting your glycogen which is making you hungry. 100 pushups for sure will be too intense and you won't be building anymore strength really.
For cardio you want to keep it low intensity and over long periods. This doesn't touch glycogen stores and optimally burns fat instead. Your lifting will use the glycogen stores but, if you're doing heavy compounds with moderate volume, your body shouldn't get too depleted.
Your weight loss will drop off the leaner you get just because your body doesn't utilise fat as efficiently. Only way around that is to eat less or just persist and trust that you'll get where you want to eventually

posts.name: Anonymous

>>69425407
>My 1st goal is to drop 10 kg in 3 months (this shouldn't be crazy as I'm 30% bf
That isn't entirely unreasonable and is certainly possible with some methods. I did it myself during 2020 > 2021 while waiting for surgery thanks to COVID delays. I can only speak from a fasting stance.

>I read that it's easier to lose fat in the beginning if you're a fat fuck.
It sure is, the weight falls off because your TDEE & BMR are much higher when you're a fat fuck.

>Does it make sense to aim for 4 kg loss in the first month?
>I know I'm overthinking things here
You are. Go with the flow, see how things work out on whichever plan/method you choose.
It's possible to do that but you're already at a "reasonable" weight compared to someone who is morbidly obese in the 115kg > 150 kg range.
You absolutely can get 4kg's lost in a month by fasting, exercising and maintenance but you're not grossly overweight.

I'm taking a look at my tracker for my fast in 2020 when I was at my biggest and I lost around 6 kilos the first month but that was with me going OMAD at first (24h) to 72/96h rolling fasts eating at TDEE on refeeds for 2 days. I don't know if that's ideal for everyone but it was what I forced to ease up on my knee.
I did that coming from a background of having "soft fasted" for years doing 72's here and there fromy my teens but going hard since I couldn't walk. I drank snek, paid attention to my electrolyes & stayed in ketosis most of the time.

Your best bet is going to be doing something like OMAD (24's) eating at your TDEE or rolling 48's again eating at your TDEE's if you choose to fast and those aren't too bad, don't require a lot of knowledge and give good results.
If you choose to do CICO eating every day at a cut, idk maybe you can do 4kg in a month but it'll be rough at your starting weight because you're not grossly over.
There's no fasting general anymore but I'm always happy to give info if people choose that path and there's other fasters around too.

While I never got that last 15 quid or what you're looking for, I did put in the work to really get the last 10-12kg off to reach my target weight when I plateaued.
I just fasted, and not the meme tier OMAD shit that I recommend to others and you see everyone else rec but I did 72's & 96's, ate at my BMR until I dropped it. I drank water, took magnesium, drank salty water, did my physio,exercise & slept.
Worked out fine for me but I'm one of the fasting fags who can push a 3-4 day fast because my diet's alredy moving around me eating less.

> Do you think forcing myself to walk thirty minutes every day
Sure thing. May or may not help. Who cares. Fuck the weight loss taking a walk for a half hour is good shit, enjoy yourself. When I was in my early 20's I used to walk for 2 & half hours every day and I was probably at my peak (ironicaly enough after being medically dischared).
> without any other life changes would be enough
Probably not, at least not short or even moderate term where you'd notice it. There's too many variables and you don't burn many calories doing it. If you're unhealthy you'll build some muscle but not enough to count.

Try cardio like the other person says, or fast it off, up to you. Fasting is rock solid, works every time but takes more effort as an "easy way" while cardio is gonna be near impossible to fuck up.

>after 7 solid months of being at a -500 deficit with only a few cheat days here and there I decided to do a 1 month maintenance mode just to slap my metabolism on the ass
>went a little overboard and was actually +200 surplus
>gained only 2lbs by the end of the month
>cut for 1 week
>instantly lose those 2 lbs and right back to my standard weight
>realize I can basically sustain myself like this once my diet is over with careful day to day tracking

Man...that shit is something I'm looking forward to. Just being able to eat 700 more calories daily completely annihilated any hunger pangs I had just from being able to fit in more food at night. Now I'm back to -500 cut and feeling the hunger but the fact that I know this is only temporary until I hit 10-12% or so BF and can switch to full on maintenance from that point on really keeps me motivated.

Honestly I think some anons could stand to come to terms with the fact that while lifestyle changes (like eating properly, lifting, cardio,etc) are indeed permanent changes for life, the whole "having to eat at a deficit" thing is 100% temporary. Things will only become easier once you finally prove you DON'T NEED that extra food and fight through it and lose all the weight you want to lose. Then you can re-introduce more (healthy) calories safely and you'll just maintain that weight as long as you don't start over-eating or slacking on your exercise.

I'm honestly REALLY motivated to finish now after that month, it was tasty as fuck to be able to add in some extra side dishes to my nightly chicken meal and I'm looking forward to having them back.

Hi schizo kun. The energy you can extract out of a meal by cleanly burning it is a sensible enough measure for the upper limit of how much energy a living organism can extract out of it. There is nothing imaginary about that. It should go without saying.
>doesn't take into account the metabolic rate
BMR is literally the vast majority of the CO part of CICO, clueless mong.
>doesn't take into account cellular metabolism
it essentially approximates cell metabolism quite significantly to its net formulas and assumes that the performance index for all macros is of roughly the same order.
>treats a 200kcal candy and a 200kcal steak as the same unit of food with the same energy intake
yes, which should tell your college dropout ass that you have a decent margin of error in the entire model, and that the entire system only works sensibly because it is assumed that you actually eat food for humans with a sensible ratio of macros and micros and not McGoyslop or Wood chips (which you can ascribe calories to no problem, doesn't mean it makes sense) as part of some autistic thought experiment.
You could easily conceive a meal plan that has formally a 200 kcal deficit with no observable weight loss.
Can you do the same for 500? 1000? I doubt it, not without going out of your way. Which means it's good enough for all practical purposes.

>are you doing a strength routine like Texas
I don't even know what that means, I have never adhered to any defined training protocols. I have a fairly simple routine which I repeat each week, with slight tweaks every couple of months to freshen things up. At this point I am pretty satisfied with my physique, so avoiding atrophy and making incremental gains is more than enough for me.
>Monday
DB bench 3x10
DB curl 3x8 + Tricep pushdown 3x12 (*Superset)
Walking BB lunges 3x?
Single arm t-bar row 3x10
Farmer's carry
Face pulls 3x10
Pull-ups to failure x 2

>Wednesday
BB OHP 3x10
DB curl 3x8 + Tricep pushdown 3x12 (*Superset)
Incline leg press 3x10 (Narrow+low foot placement), Incline leg press 3x10 (Wide+high foot placement) (*Superset)
Lat pulldown 3x10
Farmer's carry to near failure x 2
Pull-ups to failure x 2

>Friday
BB incline bench 3x10
DB curl 3x8 + Tricep pushdown 3x12 (*Superset)
Walking BB lunges 3x?
Single arm t-bar row 3x10
Farmer's carry to near failure x 2
Pull-ups to failure x 2
Standing high-to-low cable press 3x10

It's one of those items that has essentially no benefits. It exists in its own bubble of habit.
It's mostly not socially acceptable or consumed in social manners like alcohol drugs or junk food. It has commonly seen impacts on relationships and sexual health. It encourages other bad habits (e.g., using bright screens in bed at night). And it's not even the element of stress relief that some people claim -- the orgasm is the relief, not the porn itself.
Beyond those negatives, porn is just an exploitative mess with worse "hooking" algorithms than most other big businesses. That's not even getting into the more subjective elements like mental health and religious concerns.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
If you're looking to get /fit/ and stay healthy, the MD is the way to go. This diet can help reduce body fat, improve your cardiovascular health and lower your cholesterol levels. It's also great for exercise performance, since the essential nutrients in the foods it emphasizes give you energy to push yourself harder and further
>What to eat?
Mostly fruits, vegetables, whole grains, legumes, nuts, and seeds, which provide a great source of vitamins, minerals, and fiber. It also includes moderate amounts of fish, poultry, eggs, cheese, yogurt, and EVOO, which are all excellent sources of protein and healthy fats. The MD includes very little processed or red meat, making it ideal for those looking to cut back on unhealthy fats, and also avoids added sugars, refined grains, and processed foods
>What's wrong with unhealthy fats?
Eating unhealthy fats can be extremely detrimental to your health. Trans fats, saturated fats, and hydrogenated fats all increase your risk of cardiovascular disease and stroke. Eating too much of these fats can lead to high cholesterol levels, which can put you at an even higher risk of heart disease. Unhealthy fats can increase your risk of T2 diabetes and obesity. It's important to stay away from these fats and instead focus on eating healthy fats, such as monounsaturated and polyunsaturated fats. EVOO is rich in monounsaturated fats, which are more stable and less likely to oxidize, reducing the risk of forming dangerous compounds. It's also packed with antioxidants, which help protect your body from oxidative damage
>How to start?
In addition to eating healthy, it is important to engage in physical activity and get adequate sleep every night
>How to get protein?
Make sure to get lean cuts of poultry, such as chicken and turkey, and a good variety of fish and seafood in your diet. Don't forget eggs, dairy, legumes and even a moderate amount of red meat like beef, pork or lamb. Limit your red meat to just a few times a month

>>69433403
lifts in the 0-30 rep range work according to most studies, 30-50 would be fine for specific muscle groups like calves and forearms.
What you need to do is lift on a bodybuilding split while consuming protein that you can keep down.
maybe a mass gainer. at least protein shakes(I like mine with milk).
Barbell lifts do the bar for higher reps.
However with your fucked up condition you will need to know how hard you can push intensity.

You can push volume up, but you will need a certain level of intensity to grow. If you never lift near failure you will probably not grow.

Do some bodybuilding stuff at 20-30 reps and see how it feels. start light and add weight over time. If you are serious remember it's a long game most pro's are at their biggest in their 30's.

Since you are such a fan pointing to people to google, feel free to google it yourself to verify. Labor statistics such as unemployment and your metric that are based on the workforce include everyone that is both actively working or LOOKING for work. Yes, that's right. People unemployed but looking are still part of the workforce. (Separate but interesting issue during the pandemic, the workforce actually shrunk because people simply stopped looking for jobs even though they were perfectly fit to have one, which skewed some metrics during 2020/2021).

And guess what? If you're on SSI, you have to be working with a very low income, looking for a job, be extremely disabled, or over 65. So that means that, again, the 1/5 statistic is not independent of 1/3. It is mostly included in it, because the vast majority of people on SSI are still in the workforce and thus still included in the 1/3.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Happy New Year, /fit/
I'm a 33 year old oldfag and I've done my fair share of lifting and trolling over the years (started lifting at 20) and still, up to this day, many young men are misguided when it comes to lifting and being healthy. Seeing as january is here, I'll be dropping some general redpills so you newfags have it easier and don't have to commit too many mistakes in your lifting journey. I'll save you all the bullshit and get straight to the point.

General /fit/ redpills:
>Realize that becoming and staying /fit/ is a life-long journey. You will be lifting every 2-4 days (depending on recovery) for the rest of your life. Once you come to terms with this, life will become easier.
>Consistency is king. Building muscle and losing fat takes a long time. Stay consistent for long enough and you'll get results.
>Do not expect to see quick results. As a natty, 2 years is least amount of time needed to start to look like you lift (perfect routine+diet). For most wagie /fit/ normies it will take closer to 5 years.
>All diets come down to CICO. You can not escape the law of thermodynamics. There are some individuals who have hormonal disruption which prevents them from losing weight, but there's a 99% chance that you're not one of them.
>People grossly overestimate the amount of lean muscle mass they are packing and grossly underestimate the amount of fat they actually store.
>Lean/big/natty. Pick two.
>For 99% of /fit/izens, "making it" implies having a beach bod (ascended ottermode) at 10-12% bodyfat.
>You do not need to do "the big three" (squats, deadlift, bench press) to get big.
>A healthy, athletic male has a visible six pack. If you do not have visible abs, you are fat. Simple as.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Compound exercises are not enough to hit your core/abs. Doing over 9000 crunches will not give you visible abs. Abdominal, like any other exercise, benefit from your typical 6-12 hypertrophy rep range. Hanging weighted (lateral) leg raises in said range is the best overall abdominal exercise. Abs start to appear at around 13-14% bodyfat.
>Cardio is king. Swimming>cycling>running in terms of fun/efficiency. One hour session per week at the very minimum. Waterproof mp3 player for swimming sessions (Sony Walkman).
>You don't really need any supplements, you can easily get all you need from a well-planned diet. A multivitamin when cutting is a good idea.
>An adult human should not be eating 3 times a day.
>CICO keto OMAD with bulletproof coffee in the morning and fasted cardio is the most efficient way of losing fat. Keto is good for maintenance and having low bodyfat due to decreased water retention. Keto is not good for building muscle/bulking.
>Weighted calisthenics (weighted ring dips/bulgarian dips/pullups/towel chinups/hanging leg raises) in the 6-12 rep hypertrophy range with progressive overload is pretty much all you need to have a strong and muscular upper body.
>Most of fitness "influencers" are not natty.
>Do not follow a bodybuilders brosplit made for roiders with increased metabolism and recovery as a natty.
>Sleeping is essential since most of your fat loss/muscle building occurs during your sleep. By cutting your sleeping hours you are cutting your gains.
>The anabolic window is a meme. Digestion takes 6-8 hours and most of your muscle repair occurs during night when you sleep.

I'll be updating the list as time moves on. Keep lifting and stay natty.
